hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
gpt-4_1-nano_translation: Lālau (throwing) like Puali‘i (the noble/royal) with the knife (ko‘ilipi), and then he went until he reached the middle where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was kneeling, pricking at his four ‘uala (sweetpotato) stems, on top of the fire. Seeing all the children, they all ran, and they stood on a little hill out of fear of Puali‘i. Puali‘i then spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: "'Look! Here is the ko‘ilipi (knife) in my hand, it is a thing for cutting your head today, and behead, then cook with the ‘uala, and I will eat first, then it will be free (to do as I please)." But Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not listen to Puali‘i’s words, and Puali‘i then prepared to cut Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the ko‘ilipi, at that moment when Nāmakaokapāo‘i was praying his last prayers for Puali‘i. Those were his prayers: "Aloha (love/affection) only is my gaze, O eaves (no‘a) of the kea (possibly a metaphor), May it scatter, may it break apart, perhaps to eat, perhaps to leave behind—Nākukui‘aimakaokalani (the bright-eyed sky-gazing Kuki ‘aimakaokalani), that is Kukui‘aimakaokalani, my friend, Nāmakaokai‘a the great chief of Hawai‘i. Let it drift away, let the streaks of the one-hardened, the spear, the drum, die Nāmakaokapāo‘o."
gpt-4_1-nano_commentary:
• Allegorical interpretation of characters and events:
  – Puali‘i, as a figure of authority or perhaps a rogue noble, represents a threat to the community’s safety; his act of wielding a ko‘ilipi (knife) signifies violence or a dangerous test of power. The imagery of him throwing 'akula (like a spear or throwing motion) suggests aggressive intent.
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o, whose name means "Sea-Dwellers (Nāmaka) of the chiefs (pāo'o)," symbolizes a venerable and possibly sacred figure—perhaps a chief, guardian, or personification of spiritual or societal authority. His kneeling and prayerful stance reflect humility and spiritual focus in the face of danger.
  – The children’s flight signifies innocence and vulnerability, emphasizing the peril faced from the wielding of raw power or violence.

• Names and symbolic references:
  – Puali‘i: "Puali‘i" can be broken into "Pu-ali‘i" (“ruler’s gun/authority”), indicating a person with noble or commanding status, possibly corrupted or aggressive.
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o: "Nāmaka" means "sea (Nā) of (o) the full (maka) eyes or gaze," indicating a divine or oceanic intelligence; "pāo'o" often refers to a chief or principal figure, suggesting high rank or spiritual authority.
  – The phrase "Nākukui‘aimakaokalani" ("the clouds (kuki) with eyes (‘aimaka) of the sky (lani)") evokes celestial observation, perhaps symbolizing wisdom or divine oversight.

• Cultural and historical context:
  – The narrative likely echoes the Ai Kapu era (before 1819), a time of strict religious and social codes, where violence or threats to sacred authority would be critically condemned.
  – The act of prayer and invocation of divine or ancestral protection aligns with traditional Hawaiian spiritual practices, especially during times of social upheaval or threat.
  – The story's tension, involving threat and prayer, could reflect post-contact social commentaries—a critique of destructive behaviors or overreach of power, especially as Hawaiian society faced external influences after 1820 (e.g., missionaries, Western powers).

• Symbolism and deeper themes:
  – The “ko‘ilipi” (knife) within the story symbolizes not only physical violence but also the potential rupture of social harmony or kapu (sacred laws).
  – The final prayer, with references to love, scattering, and leaving behind, suggests a plea for mercy or spiritual grace amid impending destruction—possibly an allegory for societal or spiritual decay.
  – The mention of specific natural elements (the sea, clouds, the sky) emphasizes interconnectedness with nature, reflective of traditional Hawaiian worldview where natural elements are spiritual agents.

• Possible social commentary or critique:
  – The narrative may be a subtle critique of those in authority who threaten or pursue their own interests at the expense of community harmony, illustrating the peril of neglecting spiritual guidance.
  – The plea for mercy and the imagery of death and scattering could symbolize the loss of traditional values or the chaos that ensues when social order is disturbed—especially relevant during periods of colonization or societal upheaval.
  – The text’s layered symbolism encourages reflection on the importance of spiritual humility, community cohesion, and respect for sacred authority, themes central to Hawaiian cultural resilience.

Here is the ko‘ilipi (knife) in my hand, it is a thing for cutting your head today, and behead, then cook with the ‘uala, and I will eat first, then it will be free (to do as I please)." reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
